articles.title: About our project
articles.description:
This is the website to our group project that we worked on in the course of the Data Analytics seminar supervised by Dirk Wulff and Rui Mata in the spring semester of 2022, at the Faculty of Psychology, University of Basel.

In the course of the semester, this website was regularly updated to the state of our project that we concluded with our final project presentation on May 25, 2022.

We hope you enjoy reading it!

articles.title: Data Analytics Project | 'We live in an economically globalized, but socially only superficially globalized world!'
articles.description: Elea Bornand & Roman Alt | Spring Semester 2022, University of Basel
articles.contents:
1 Introduction to the Topic
On February 24, 2022 Russia invaded Ukraine. The invasion
represents a momentous escalation of the Russo-Ukrainian War that
has been going on since 2014. The war mainly revolves around the status
of strategically significant regions (e.g., Alfarsi, 2022).
Since the invasion, over 4.1 million Ukrainian citizens have suddenly
had to flee their home country into the unknown (as of May 18, 2022;
Global Conflict Tracker, 2022). People around the globe are moved by the
horrifying circumstances Ukrainians have since been facing day-to-day.
The Russia-Ukraine Conflict is all over the news and social
media, e.g., Twitter.
1.1 Twitter
Twitter is a popular “online, global microblog and social networking
service“ (Dodds et al., 2011) with 500 million tweets per day by 217
million daily active users (i.e., tweeters; as of February 21, 2022;
Selected Company Metrics and Financials, 2022). But how do tweeters feel
towards the matters they choose to address? To what extent do their
tweets indicate sentiments, e.g., happiness? What words do they use to
express their thoughts on the matters?
1.2 Hedonometer
Quantifying happiness is what the Hedonometer
(hedonometer.org) aims at: It meters (and visualizes) Twitter users’
“hedonistic“ (positive) emotions (i.e., happiness in this case). Like
other sentiment analysis techniques, it assigns sentiment (happiness)
scores (ranging continuously from (1) least to (9) most
happy) to textual data based on the words included. To do so, it is
fed with wordlists corresponding to the language the textual data is in.
Wordlists related to the Hedonometer currently exist in ten different
languages, e.g., English, German, Russian and Ukrainian. The
Hedonometer computes the weighted average happiness of text through the
following equation (Qiao & Jiang, 2022):

Figure 1: The equation the hedonometer computes the weighted average
happiness score through (Qiao & Jiang, 2022).


wi: word in the text


fi: frequency of word


N: number of unique words


havg: average happiness


havg(T): average happiness of the whole text


havg(wi): average happiness of a word


pi: normalized frequency

Some of the
Hedonometer’s Advantages are:

It is capable of processing large, real-time textual data
rapidly. This enables to gain large-scale insights into social phenomena
(Dodds & Danforth, 2009; Johnson & Alluri, 2016).


Unlike surveys, it does not depend on people’s self-reports of their
emotional states (Dodds et al., 2011).


The Hedonometer’s ways of processing data are transparent, therefore,
their improvement is not restricted to its development team (Dodds &
Danforth, 2009).

1.3
Motivation – What motivates us to work towards answering our research
question (see section below)?

Since the question revolves around an (unfortunately) ongoing conflict
(We obviously wish for the conflict to end as soon and peacefully as
possible.), it is highly topical. The Hedonometer data is newly and
continuously collected.


Twitter is a widely used social networking service (Dodds et al., 2011;
Selected Company Metrics and Financials, 2022).


Our motivation to initially focus on the topic of sentiment analyses:
expand what we have theoretically learnt about them in the course of a
seminar (Research methods in Human-Computer Interaction 1) held by the
University’s Human-Computer Interaction department in the fall semester
2021.


Most significantly: Terrible incidents take place every day, all around
the globe. With most people having access to some sort of (online)
media, news spread easily and can be commented on by anyone, speaking
any language, being more or less distantly located to and (to different
degrees) economically dependent on incidents’ regional origins. Usually,
people feel affected by (and like discussing) incidents as long as they
appear topical to them. For the most part, the time spent informing
oneself, thinking and talking about incidents decreases over time, other
things become personally more significant (e.g., concerning everyday
life; closely related people). People are usually unaware of the
economic relationships their home countries maintain with other
countries in the world. Import/export are relatively abstract constructs
to most people, exclusively cared about by those who can be held
responsible for. Hyperbolically put, it is generally not until the
newest iPhone can’t be shipped and delivered quickly to their front
door, that “average“ people begin worrying about those economic
relationships. It might be of interest to policymakers to increase this
awareness. A thought relevant to democratic nations: An overall informed
citizen also is a more competent voter.

2 Our project
2.1 Research Question &
Outcome Variables
On February, 24 and the days following, a drop in all
languages’ average happiness scores can be noticed. However, shortly
after, the scores increase again. This could be due to a habituation
effect, similar to the one regarding the COVID-19 pandemic that has
been observed by Dan and Brosius (2021). We, therefore, are
interested in addressing the following research question:
How
do average happiness scores of Twitter users tweeting in different
languages develop after February, 24 (i.e., day Russia first invaded
Ukraine)?
To find answers to this question, we look at two outcome
variables:

Reactivity outcome: average happiness scores (mean, standard
deviation) one day after the invasion, compared to the average
happiness scores one day before the invasion  probable drop in
average happiness scores (see Hypotheses)


Habituation: average happiness scores (mean, standard deviation)
two weeks after the invasion, compared to the baseline (see next
paragraph) -> tweeters in some languages will likely (already) have
recovered from their “happiness drop“/returned to their baseline, while
others will not have recovered entirely from their drop/will not have
returned to their baseline (yet) (see Hypotheses)

A baseline (average happiness scores) is needed for the above outcome
variables:

Baseline: average happiness scores one month prior to the
invasion

We collected further data on the countries speaking one of the
Hedonometer languages:

Their capital via [API]: These data were used to calculate each
country’s (capital’s) geodistance to Ukraine (Kiev) in
kilometers.


A balanced value of import from as well as export to Ukraine in US
dollars via https://data.imf.org/?sk=9d6028d4-f14a-464c-a2f2-59b2cd424b85&sId=1515619375491

We initially had intended to incorporate more variables, for instance
import from and export to Russia. We then would have had to research
information on sanctions possibly imposed on Russia for all countries,
which would have made our analysis a lot more complex. So, we decided to
stick to the most important variables: geodistance and import
from/export to Ukraine.
2.2 Hypotheses

On Geodistance: We hypothesize that geodistance has a systematic
effect on people’s affectedness (operationalized as the development of
their happiness scores): Twitter users who are geographically
less (vs. more) distantly located to Ukraine (i.e., hotspot of
the conflict) therefore are expected to show stronger drops in
their average happiness scores (reactivity outcome) and (therefore) take
longer (i.e., more days since the invasion) to recover from the
drop/still not have returned to their baseline (habituation).


On Economic relationship: We hypothesize that countries’ economic
relationship to Ukraine does not have a systematic effect on
people’s affectedness (operationalized as the development of their
happiness scores): Twitter users therefore are expected to show a
development of their average happiness scores (reactivity outcome) and
time to return to their baseline (habituation) that is not
systematically related to their countries’ economic relationship to
Ukraine. This is thought to be due to unawareness of the economic
relationships and ways those might be affected by the conflict.

2.3 Methodology
We were advised to focus on data visualization, as (1)
this would be most effective to communicate our results to any audience
not familiar with our project, and because (2) the time to work
on our project was limited. So, the goal ultimately became to
visualize our outcome variables (i.e., reactivity outcome and
habituation) and in what ways they vary as a function of our predictor
variables (i.e., geodistance and economic relationship). We
first collected the processed data from hedonometer.org as well as the
variables Language, Capital and Iso2 code (i.e., standard code) for all
relevant countries. [Work in progress.]
3 Difficulties & Learnings
3.1 Languages ≠ Countries
Hedonometrics only differentiate between tweeters’ languages, not the
countries they are located in. We therefore were challenged to find a
way to still fit the data to our research question. We decided to focus
on countries’ first national language.Countries
in which languages included in the “Hedonometrics“ are
officially spoken (in alphabetical order; Infoplease, 2022):

Spanish (second most widely spoken language): Argentina; Bolivia;
Chile; Colombia; Costa Rica; Cuba; Dominican Republic; East Timor;
Ecuador; El Salvador; Equatorial Guinea; Guatemala; Honduras; Mexico;
Micronesia; Nicaragua; Panama; Paraguay; Peru; Spain; Uruguay; Venezuela


English (third most widely spoken language): Antigua and Barbuda;
Barbados; Belize; Botswana; Burundi; Cameroon; Canada; Cape Verde;
Dominica; Eritrea; Eswatini; Fiji; Grenada; Guyana; Ireland; Kenya;
Kiribati; Lesotho; Liberia; Malawi; Malta; Namibia; New Zealand;
Nigeria; Pakistan; Palau; Palestinian State; Papua New Guinea;
Philippines; Rwanda; Samoa; Seychelles; Sierra Leone; Singapore; Solomon
Islands; South Africa; South Sudan; Sudan; Tanzania; Tonga; Trinidad and
Tobago; Tuvalu; Uganda; United Kingdom; United States; Vanuatu; Zambia;
Zimbabwe


Arabic (fifth most widely spoken language): Algeria; Bahrain;
Chad; Comoros; Djibouti; Egypt; Eritrea; Iraq; Jordan; Kuwait; Lebanon;
Libya; Mauritania; Morocco; Oman; Qatar; Saudi Arabia; Somalia; Sudan;
Syria; Tunisia; United Arab Emirates; Yemen


Portuguese (seventh most widely spoken language): Angola; Brazil;
Equatorial Guinea; Guinea-Bissau; Mozambique; Myanmar; Portugal;
Democratic Republic of São Tomé and Príncipe


Russian (eighth most widely spoken language): Belarus;
Kazakhstan; Kyrgyzstan; Russia


Chinese: China; Taiwan


French: Belgium; Benin; Burkina Faso; Burundi; Cameroon; Canada;
Cape Verde; Central African Republic; Chad; Comoros; Democratic Republic
of the Congo; Republic of Congo; Côte d’Ivoire; Djibouti; Equatorial
Guinea; France; Gabon; Gambia; Guinea; Haiti; Luxembourg; Madagascar;
Mali; Monaco; Niger; Rwanda; Senegal; Seychelles; Switzerland; Togo;
Vanuatu


German: Austria; Belgium; Germany; Italy; Liechtenstein;
Luxembourg; Switzerland


Korean: North Korea; South Korea


Ukrainian: Ukraine

3.2
Non-availability of Absolute Number of Twitter Users per Country
Our idea was to weight geodistance (to Kiev) and economic
relationship according to the absolute number of Twitter users per
country which is part of one of the Hedonometer’s language groups.
Unfortunately, we were unable to find data on absolute numbers of
Twitter users per country. We found this list of numbers instead: https://www.statista.com/statistics/242606/number-of-active-twitter-users-in-selected-countries/
 However, only thirteen of the 20 listed countries speak one
of the Hedonometer’s language. We therefore were advised to
still use this list, but to set the weight of countries not mentioned in
the list to the minimum value in the list.
3.3 Manually generated Data
vs. APIs
Before we learnt that there basically is an API to any data one might
be in need of, we had already researched and typed in (Google
spreadsheet) most geodistance and some economic relationship values by
hand. The following links lead to the sites we had then used:

Geodistance: https://www.distance.to/


Economic relationship: https://oec.world/en/profile/country/ukr

Obviously, this manual approach was time-consuming and non-necessary
– and we for sure were glad to learn about the APIs – after all, it at
least helped to get a first feel for the data.

4 Results
Currently, we can display the development of the average happiness
score as well as a baseline graph before the 24.2.2022 (i.e., first day
of invasion) for German Twitter users. Also, we’ve got the
processed Hedonometer data as well as the variables Language, Capital
and Iso2 code for all relevant countries.

[Work in progress.]
